data.text:
Writers' Center brings books, breakfast to Cummaquid

Today from 9:30 to 11:30 a.m. at the Harbor Point Restaurant, the Cape Cod Writers' Center will hold a Breakfast With the Authors. This month's event will feature Patry Francis, author of The Liar's Diary; Dorothy Leone, author of Where the Herring Run; Valerie Lawson, author of the poetry collection Dog Watch; and Merrily B. Fenner and Joan Walsh, author and illustrator of the children's book The Secret. Tickets are $12 at the door. Coffee, juice and pastries will be served. For more information or to reserve a seat, contact the Writers' Center at 508-420-0200 or writers@capecodwriterscenter.org.

Sturgis Library

Ongoing book sales are Tuesdays and Thursdays from 1:30 to 4 p.m. and Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. at the library on Route 6A in Barnstable. Call 508-362-6636 for more information.

Book sale at Osterville Village Library

Pre-school stories and activities for ages 3 to 5 take place Tuesdays from 1:30 to 2:15 p.m. To pre-register, call 508-428-5757.

Barnes & Noble

A book club focusing on personal growth and spirituality meets at 9:30 a.m. the second Wednesday of every month.

Reservations are not required for activities. For more information, call 508-862-6310.

Borders Books

A writer's group meets weekly on Tuesday nights at 6:30 to socialize and exchange feedback on work. For more information, call 508-477-1120 or e-mail 1extraoordinary.machine@gmail.com.

Weekly story times and events are also offered. For more information, call 508-362-6363.

Inkwell Bookstore

A quilting group meets on select Fridays and a knitting group meets on Thursdays at 6:30 p.m. at the Inkwell Bookstore, 199 Main St. in Falmouth, 508-540-0039.

Brewster Ladies' Library

The Brewster Ladies' Library offers a variety of book discussions throughout the spring. For more information, go to www.brewsterladieslibrary.org or call 508-896-3913.

CANVAS

CCftA features a class with glass

The Cotuit Center for the Arts, 4404 Route 28 in Cotuit, will offer a four-week workshop for beginners on the construction of stained-glass windows. Beginning May 1, instructor Kim Croft will conduct three-hour classes meant to teach students how to work from a pattern, cut glass, use a glass grinder and use various hand tools. Patterns will be provided but students should provide glass and tools. Cost for the series is $250. For more information or to register, call 508-428-0669.

Cahoon Museum features the ABCs and 123s of abstract art

Through June 17, the Cahoon Museum of American Art, 4676 Falmouth Road in Cotuit, will feature two companion shows on abstract art. "The ABCs of Abstract" will showcase how abstract art happened and "4 by 10" will discuss what it means. An opening reception for both shows will be held May 11 from 5 to 7 p.m. The event will feature refreshments and Bob Schneider on piano.

The Cahoon Museum is open 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Tuesday through Saturday and 1 to 4 p.m. Sunday. Admission is $4 for adults and free for children under 12. For more information, call 508-428-7581.

New works in an old gallery

The Old Selectmen's Building Gallery, Meetinghouse Way, a historic building in Barnstable, features weekly exhibits featuring a variety of local artists and media. The gallery is open to the public.

Through April 29, the gallery will feature Karen Gula's "Visions in Time," an exhibition of acrylics, oils and photography.

The gallery is open Wednesday through Saturday from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. and Sunday from noon to 4 p.m.

Are you gifted?

Gift of Art, a gallery for professional artists and crafts-people at 544 Main St. in Hyannis, welcomes submissions for jury selection and exhibition. Contact Susan Patev at seahagsue@msn.com or Robert Carter at Robert.carter@umb.edu.

Beads and baubles

Learn the art of glass bead making at Leslie B. Spencer's Fine Arts and Crafts Studio, 151 Main St. in Cotuit. Call 508-420-2343.

Conservatory encourages creativity

Through April 27, the Conservatory will feature an exhibition of realistic and abstract paintings and photographs by local artist Christina.

Registration is also open for the Cape Cod Conservatory Fine and Performing Arts classes. Students of all ages are welcome. For details, call 508-362-2772 or go to www.capecodconservatory.net. The conservatory is located at 2235 Route 132 in West Barnstable.

Pastel Society paints the town

From May 2 to June 7, Highfield Hall, 56 Highfield Drive in Falmouth will feature an exhibition of artists from the Pastel Painters' Society of Cape Cod. An opening reception will be held May 4 from 5 to 7 p.m. On May 9 at 11:30 a.m., PPSCC signature member Edith Cohenno Bryant will offer a gallery talk and luncheon. Cost for the event is $30.

Highfield Hall is open Monday through Friday from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. and other times by appointment. For more information or to reserve a space, call 508-495-1878 ext. 6.

Creative Arts Center offers pulpy exhibit

On May 5 and 6 from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., the Creative Arts Center, 154 Crowell Road in Chatham, will feature its second annual Artisans In Wood show and sale. Demonstrations, wood decoy appraisal and a reception featuring Cape-wide carving clubs are included. Admission is free.

Children's Museum flips out

The Cape Cod Children's Museum, 577 Great Neck Road South in Mashpee, will hold its third annual Flip-Flop Fling on May 6 at the Beachmoor Inn and Restaurant in Buzzard's Bay. The event will feature music, buffet, cocktails, silent auctions, a 50/50 raffle, door prizes and gifts. Dress is Cape Cod casual. Tickets are $50 and can be purchased at the museum or by calling 508-539-8788.

Spring Fling in Provincetown

From May 5 through May 29, the Bowersock Gallery, 373 Commercial St. in Provincetown, will host its Spring Fling exhibit, featuring new and veteran artists' works. An opening reception will be held May 5 from 4 to 7 p.m.

Yarmouth banks on art

Through May 23, the Yarmouth Art Guild is showing the works of artist Nancy Way at the Sovereign Bank on Route 28 in South Yarmouth.

Free museum admission in May

Through the month of May, Bank of America's Museums on Us program will offer free admission to various museums to its cardholders. Participating Cape museums include the Cape Cod Museum of Art and the Provincetown Art Association and Museum.

Mayflower Place colors the Cape beautiful

Michael Helfen's exhibition "The Color of Beauty," will be on display at Mayflower Place Retirement Community, 579 Buck Island Road in West Yarmouth, through May 13. For more information, call 508-790-0200.

Good vibrations

Welstar art gallery, 42 South Orleans Road in Orleans, will hold feature the paintings of Anne Salas through June 17 in its exhibit "Spring Vibrations." For more information, call 508-240-1422 or visit www.welstar.net.

Spring flings at the CCMA

The Cape Cod Museum of Art features a variety of rotating exhibits. Currently on display is a new show honoring the life and work of the late local artist Betty Lane, whose centennial is observed this year.

On Sunday from 5:30 to 8 p.m., the CCMA will hold its fourth annual spring wine tasting event. Wine tastings, food from various Cape restaurants, music and prizes will be available. Cost for the event is $50 for CCMA members, $60 for non-members; $275 or $335 for a group of six; or $450 or $550 for a group of 10. For reservations, call 508-385-4477 ext. or go to www.ccmoa.org/specialevents.

On May 7, the Friends of the CCMA will host its annual benefit spring luncheon and fashion show at the 28 Atlantic restaurant at the Wequasset Inn Resort and Golf Club in Chatham. Fashions by Irresistibles of Mashpee and Pentimento of Chatham will be featured. Cost for the event is $40 for Friends members and $45 for non-members. For reservations or more information, call Helene Savicki at 508-385-8835.

The CCMA off Route 6A in Dennis is open Tuesday through Saturday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., Thursdays until 8 p.m., and Sundays from noon to 5 p.m. For more information on the museum, call 508-385-4477 ext. 12 or visit www.ccmoa.org.

Artful Thursdays at Dennis museum

On select weeks, the Cape Cod Museum of Art in Dennis will have special events for its Artful Thursdays.

On May 3 from 5:30 to 7:30 p.m., the CCMA will hold its final One Night Stand for the season. Artists Ray Nolin and Jodie Hodson will work together to create a print at "Inside the Artists' Atelier." Music will be provided by Brenda Evans, and wine and refreshments will be served.

Meet your friends, spend time at the museum and then take in lunch or dinner at local restaurants offering Artful Thursdays 10 percent discounts: The Mercantile and the Blue Moon Bistro.

Liberty Hall Club features feast

Tomorrow from 5 to 6:30 p.m., the Liberty Hall Club of Marstons Mills will hold a roast beef dinner at the club on Main Street. Tickets for the meal are $10 and can be purchased at Marstons Mills Library and at the Liberty Hall Club on the day of the event. Take-out meals will be available. For more information, call 508-420-3147 or 508-428-8605.

Go fish (and feast) with Trout Unlimited

The Cape Cod chapter of Trout Unlimited will host its annual fundraising banquet on April 29 at the Harbor Point Restaurant, Route 6A in Cummaquid. The event will feature a buffet dinner, raffles, door prizes and a silent auction, with proceeds going toward the group's efforts to restoring cold-water fisheries. Tickets are $35. For more information or to reserve a spot, call Wayne Miller at 508-362-3678. Checks can be made payable to CCTU and sent to Wayne Miller, P.O. Box 711 in West Barnstable.

Cape Cod Glass Club

On May 1, the Cape Cod Class Club will meet for a field trip to the Fritz Glass Studio. Lunch will be held at noon at Clancy's, 8 Upper County Road in Dennisport. After lunch the club will visit Fritz's studio. For more information or to reserve a spot at lunch, call 508-362-6875.

German-American Club celebrates 30 years

On May 12, the German-American Club of Cape Cod will hold a 30th anniversary party at the Fraternal Lodge in Centerville. The evening will feature a meal with traditional foods, a champagne toast and a cash bar. Cost is $22 per person. The public is welcome to attend. For more information or reservations, contact Pamela Brimmer at 508-385-2735.

Cotuit Bird and Garden Club meetings

The Cotuit Bird and Garden Club meets the second Wednesday of each month at 10 a.m. at the Cotuit Library on Main Street. The meeting is open to all. For more information, call 508-428-5928

Cape Cod Bird Club

Meetings are held the second Monday of every month at 7:30 p.m. at the Cape Cod Museum of Natural History, Route 6A in Brewster. Meetings are free and open to the public.

For kids of all ages

An intergenerational program at the Barnstable Senior Center, 825 Falmouth Road in Hyannis, meets the first and third Tuesday of each month at 10:30 a.m. for games, crafts, refreshments, sing-alongs and more. All ages are welcome. Call 508-420-3477 for more information.

Cape Cod Hospital Auxiliary

Members of the Cape Cod Hospital Auxiliary Barnstable Branch meet the second Thursday of the month at St. Mary's Church in Barnstable Village at 10:30 a.m. A social gathering follows the brief meeting with guest speakers. All are welcome.

Camera club at art association

The Cape Cod Art Association camera club meets at 7 p.m. every other Thursday at the CCAA on Route 6A in Barnstable. Meetings feature guest speakers, critiques, contests, workshops, photo sessions and more.

Group for Barnstable youths

The Barnstable Youth Commission and its Youth Empowered Through Learning Leadership advisory group meet at 2 p.m. every first and third Thursday in room 2108 at Barnstable High School. Ages 13 through 19 are invited to discuss issues affecting the young people of Barnstable.

Barnstable Newcomers

Meetings are held the third Wednesday of the month at the Barnstable Senior Center, 825 Falmouth Road in Hyannis, at 7:30 p.m. Meetings include a speaker and a social gathering. Annual membership is $10. For more information, call Deb Krau at 508-778-1756 or visit www.barnstablenewcomers.com.

BARS meets monthly in West Barnstable

Members of the Barnstable Association for Recreational Shellfishing meet the first Tuesday of the month at the West Barnstable Community Building, Route 149 (Meetinghouse Road), at 7 p.m. for guest speakers, programs, events and updates on town projects. Log on to the newly redesigned www.shellfishing.org for more information.

Cape & Islands Gay & Straight Youth Alliance (CIGSYA)

CIGSYA House, 56 Barnstable Road in Hyannis offers support and more for those 22 and under in the community. For more information, call 508-255-9897 or go to www.CIGSYA.org.

The Cape & Islands Gay & Straight Youth Alliance has a dance room, cyber center, library, TV room and game room as well as several programs and activities.

There are monthly dances, support meetings for all family members, movie nights, potluck dinners, tutoring and mentoring.

Circle for Youth meets from 3 to 5:30 p.m. on Mondays at the clubhouse. Activities include creative writing, visual art, dance, theater and more. A new conversational group for people who have questions about gender meets the second and fourth Wednesday of the month at 8 p.m.

Barnstable-Yarmouth Lions Club

This organization of men and women raises funds for eye research and other community services. Meetings are held at the Wianno Grille on the first and third Tuesdays of the month at 6:30 p.m. For more information, call 508-534-6099.

Needlepointers in Dennis

The Cape Cod Chapter of the American Needlepoint Guild meets the second Monday of the month at Carleton Hall in Dennis at 9:30 a.m. For information, call 508-759-9248.

The Garden Club of Hyannis

The Garden Club of Hyannis (GCFM-NGC) meets the third Tuesday of the month at the Federated Church of Hyannis, 320 Main St., at noon. The public is welcome for a small donation.

Cape Cod Gay Men's Chorus

Members of the chorus meet weekly on Tuesday night at 7:30 to rehearse at the Cape Cod and Island Gay/Straight Youth Alliance House, Elm Avenue and Barnstable Road in Hyannis. New singers and musicians always welcome.

Astronomical Society meets at D-Y

All are invited to meetings of the Cape Cod Astronomical Society at 7:30 p.m. on the first Thursday of the month at Dennis-Yarmouth Regional High School on Station Avenue in South Yarmouth.

Linux User Group meetings

Mid Cape Linux User Group www.midcapelinux.org meets the first Tuesday of every month at 7 p.m. at Area 52, Whites Path, South Yarmouth. Meetings are free and open to the public. Log on to www.midcapelinux.org.

Paranormal group opens meetings to public

The Cape & Islands Paranormal Research Society will open one meeting a month, usually on the final Friday, to the general public, from 7 to 9 p.m. For more information, call 508-224-7321 or visit www.caiprs.com.

Habitat for Humanity of Cape Cod

Mid-Cape chapter meetings are held the first Wednesday of each month at 7 p.m. at the Barnstable Unitarian Church on Route 6A.

Cape Cod Motorcycle Club

Members of the Cape Cod Motorcycle Club meet at 7:30 p.m. the first and third Tuesday of the month at Child and Family Services of Cape Cod, 1019 Iyannough Road in Hyannis. Motorcycles 350cc and above are welcome. The club is American Motorcycle Association-sanctioned. Call 508-775-3793 for more information.

Villages of Barnstable Women's Club

The Villages of Barnstable (Jr.) Women's Club meets the first Thursday of the month at 7 p.m. at Whelden Memorial Library on Route 149 in West Barnstable. For more information or to become a member, call 508-420-3477.

Veterans For Peace

The Cape Cod chapter of Veterans For Peace meets the first Wednesday of each month in Hyannis. Call 508-420-5532 or 508-771-3915. The club is dedicated to the peaceful prevention of deadly conflict everywhere.

Veterans of Foreign Wars

The VFW Hall holds meetings for its members throughout each month. For more information on the hall or its activities, call 508-775-9817.

Cape Cod Civil War Round Table

Members of the Cape Cod Civil War Round Table meet the first and third Tuesday of each month year-round to present informal talks, give book reports and share stories about visits to Civil War sites. Gatherings take place from 7 to 9 p.m. at the Riverview School on Route 6A in Sandwich.

Sandwich Women's Club name change

The Sandwich Women's Club, formerly the Sandwich Junior Women's Club, recently voted to change its name to recognize the wide range of ages in the club. For more information or to get involved, call Amy at 508-539-3588 or e-mail info@sandwichwomensclub.org.

4Cs foreign film screenings

Films in the 4Cs foreign film series are screened every Tuesday and are free to the public.

On May 1, the college will show Something Like Happiness, an award-winning Czech film chronicling the lives of three childhood friends. In Czech with English subtitles.

Showings are held in Lecture Hall A of the science building at CCCC. For more information, call Cindy Pavlos at 1-508-362-2131 ext. 4337.

Senior center features flicks

Every Monday and Friday at 1 p.m., the Barnstable Senior Center, 825 Route 28 in Hyannis, offers free public showings of popular movies.

On April 30, the center will show School for Scoundrels.

For more information on the films or showings, call Activity Coordinator Cindy Dabkowski at 508-862-4761.

Whelden Library

Children ages 3 to 5 are invited to attend story hour at Whelden Library in West Barnstable Thursday mornings from 10 to 11. Call the library on Route 149 for details on programs at 508-362-2262.

Barnes & NobleTuesday toddler story time is at 10 a.m. with preschool story time every Wednesday at 11 a.m. On Fridays there is a special story time for school-age children at 7 p.m.

For more information, call 508-862-6310.

Cotuit Library

Story times at the Cotuit Library are Tuesdays at 10:30 a.m. and Wednesdays at 2:15 p.m. Preschoolers are welcome for stories, songs and crafts.

Borders Books

Miss Sandy reads for story time at 11 a.m. on Saturdays at the store on Route 132 in Hyannis.

Eastham Public Library

The Eastham Public Library has weekly story time Fridays at 10:30 a.m. for children up to age 5. A craft session follows. The library also hosts a monthly "Magic: the Gathering" trading card game program for ages 11 and up the first Tuesday of each month from 6:15 to 7:45 p.m.

All programs are free, but advance sign-up is required.

To register, visit the Youth Services Room or contact Natalie Marsh at 508-240-5940 or by e-mail at marsh@easthamlibrary.org.

Brewster Ladies' Library

Every Wednesday at 10 a.m. in the children's room, the library offers story hour. On Fridays at 10 a.m. is toddler time. For more information about the library's activities, call Kathy Mahoney in Children's Services at 508-896-3913 ext. 16.

CCMA offers classes for kids

The Cape Cod Museum of Art's Weny Education Center is accepting students to its spring children's classes. Classes include Chinese brush painting, Budding Artists, For information on times, dates and ages call 508-385-4477 ext. 25.

Comcast seeks kids for student art contest

Through May 4, the Arts Foundation of Cape Cod is accepting applications for the fourth annual Comcast Cape-wide student t-shirt art contest. The winning design will be featured on the official t-shirt for the 22nd annual Pops by the Sea Concert. Contest winners and their high school art departments will receive art scholarships: $500 for first prize, $250 for second prize and $100 for third prize. All entrants will receive two tickets to the concert.

For more information on the contest, call 508-362-0066 or visit www.artsfoundation.org.

4-H activities

Students in grades four through seven are invited to participate in 4-H projects such as arts, crafts, quilting, gardening, community service and more. On Mondays from 3:30 to 4:15 p.m. Through May 21, the 4-H club will offer a sewing club for third and fourth graders at the Barnstable Senior Center. Call 508-420-3453 for details. The club meets the second and fourth Wednesdays of the month. Call 508-375-6696 to sign up.

Y not let kids have a night out?

The YMCA of Cape Cod, Route 132 in West Barnstable, hosts a Kids Night Out Program when children are invited to swim, play sports, create arts and crafts and more each Friday evening from 6 to 8:30 p.m. The program is staff-supervised. Register by calling Sue at 508-362-6500 ext. 110.

Rec night for teens

The YMCA invites grades 5 and 6 to teen recreation night held the first Saturday of the month from 7:15 to 9:45 p.m. at the Y, Route 132 in West Barnstable. Admission ranges from free to $3. Grades 7 and 8 are invited to teen dances the second Saturday of the month from 7:15 to 9:45 p.m. Admission is free to $5.

Y wait? YMCA offers school-age programs

The YMCA Cape Cod has openings in its school age programs in West Barnstable at the Y and in Sandwich at the Camp Lyndon Center. Instructional and recreational swim, arts projects, homework help and more are available. Call 508-362-6500 ext. 115, for details.

Village Music for voice, piano and kindermusik

Village Music offers private lessons in voice and piano and classes in Kindermusik, and early childhood music and movement class for newborns to kids up to seven years old. For more information, contact Norma Atwood at 508-394-5300 or villagemusic@mindspring.com.

Kindermusik for children

Preschool music classes for ages 18 months to four years are ongoing at the South Congregational Church in Centerville for $9 a class. Kindergarten-age children are invited to attend Kindermusik young child classes Tuesdays from 1:30 to 2:30 p.m. at the church. Admission is $10. Call 508-778-6679 or visit Musicalplayground.net.

Childcare openings in Harwich

The YMCA of Cape Cod has several openings for infant care in their Harwich and West Barnstable childcare centers. For more information, call 508-362-6500 ext. 108.

Programs at the Boys & Girls Club

The Boys & Girls Club in Mashpee is offering new programs, including a museum travel club on Wednesdays at 3 p.m., guitar lessons on Mondays at 3:30 p.m., a junior golf clinic on Thursdays at 4 p.m. and other programs.

The club is open Monday through Friday from 2 to 6 p.m. Teen nights are held every weeknight from 6 to 8 p.m. Friday night the clubhouse is open from 6 to 10 p.m. for teens. The club is open every Saturday as well as during vacation weeks.

Call 508-477-8845 for details. Membership is $25 annually.

Learn to fling!

The Callanish School of Celtic Arts leads beginning lessons in Highland Dance and Scottish Step Dance Monday afternoons at the West Barnstable Community Building on Route 149 and at the First Congregational Church of Yarmouthport on Route 6A on Wednesday afternoons. Ages 4 and up are welcome. Call 508-888-0107 for information.

Programs at the children's museum

The Cape Cod Children's Museum, 577 Great Neck Rd. South in Mashpee, offers toddler time, pre-k prep, infant time, Down on the Farm, American Red Cross babysitting, story and craft hour, a cooking class and more. For details, call 508-539-8788.

Thornton W. Burgess Society

4 Water St. in Sandwich; Green Briar Nature Center, 6 Discovery Hill Rd., East Sandwich. Hours are Monday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. For more information call 508-888-6870 or visit www.thorntonburgess.org.

Each Friday, the Society offers story times and critter capers at 10:30 a.m. Every Saturday morning at 10:30 visit with the Society's small animals and hear tales of Peter Rabbit and Friends.

These programs are free for members of the society, $1 for nonmembers. For more information on the programs, call 508-888-6870.

Evensong Coffeehouse gets Cosy

Tonight at 7 p.m., the South Congregational Church Evensong Coffeehouse, 565 Main St. in Centerville, will present a concert by singer-songwriter Cosy Sheridan. Sheridan will be accompanied by songwriter and bass player TR Ritchie. Cost for the evening is $10 for church members and students under 18 and $15 for general admission.

More fun than a cheap cigar

The Rum Soaked Crooks (that's an old brand name for a big stogie) roll into the Cape Cod Maritime Museum tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. for an evening of chanteys on Hyannis inner harbor. Admission, which includes dessert and beverage, is $12. For reservations, call Cathrine Macort at 508-775-1723 or send an e-mail to lchmacort@yahoo.com.

APA gets connected to Connecticut

Tomorrow at 8 p.m. in the Grand Ball Room of the Four Points Sheraton in Eastham, the Academy of Performing Arts will present Dance to the Music, a benefit concert and dance featuring music by the Connecticut Connection, a 12-member rock band featuring Harwich vocalist Caitlin Mills. A cash bar and appetizers will also be offered. Tickets for the event are $15 in advance and $20 at the door, and all proceeds will benefit the Academy's scholarship program. For more information or to purchase tickets call 508-255-5510.

Puccini Project comes to the Cape

Sunday at 3 p.m. at Cape Cod Community College's Tilden Arts Center, Opera of New England will present Puccini's Manon Lescaut directed by Michael Capasso of the Puccini Project. At 1:30 p.m. Capasso will present a preview of the opera. Tickets for the event are offered at $54, $42 and $25. Tickets for the preview are free for contributors of $25 or more and $5 for others. To purchase tickets, call 508-771-3600. For credit card sales visit www.capetix.com, www.theatermania.com or call 866-811-4111.

Soul group helps the Cape feel good

Tomorrow from 8 p.m. to midnight, Delaware Floyd Brown and the Boston Soul Revue Band will get on up at the Sons of Italy in Mashpee to raise money for autism. Brown and his band will play a variety of soul favorites. Tickets are $20 and are available at Kinlin Grover of Osterville, at the door or at 508-420-1130 ext. 133.

Bach to Bach cantatas

Tomorrow at 8 p.m. and Sunday at 3 p.m., the Chatham Chorale and the Cape Sinfonietta will present "A Festival of Cantatas" featuring the works of Bach. The event will feature soloists Krista River, Aaron Sheehan and Sumner Thompson.

Performances will take place at the Mattacheese Middle School, Higgins Crowell Road in West Yarmouth. Tickets are $25 reserved, $20 open seating and free for those 18 and under and can be purchased at Puritan stores in Hyannis or Chatham or at 1-888-556-2707.

Woods Hole brings songs to the sea

Sunday at 7:30 p.m. at the Community Hall, 68 Water St. in Woods Hole, the Woods Hole Folk Music Society will present a concert by Scottish singer Emily Smith. Doors open at 7 p.m. Tickets are $10 for society members and $12 for non-members. Discounts are available for children and seniors. For more information or to reserve tickets, call 508-540-0320 or visit www.arts-cape.com/whfolkmusic.

UMass Amherst drums up support

The UMass Amherst Cape Cod Alumni Club will holds its annual fundraising concert, featuring the UMass Amherst Concert Band directed by George N. Parks, on May 1 at 7:30 p.m. The performance will take place at Cape Cod Community College's Tilden Arts Center. Tickets are $15 for adults and $10 for students and can be purchased at Puritan Clothing, the 4Cs box office, at the door or by calling 508-362-9460.

West Barnstable is held Captive by the music

On May 5 at 7:30 p.m., First Lutheran Church, 1663 Main St. in West Barnstable, will present a concert by the Captive Free Band, a music ministry team. A free will offering will be accepted. For more information, contact the church office at 508-362-3161.

Cape Community Orchestra gets springy

The Cape Community Orchestra, a group comprised of Cape musicians of all ages, will host two days of its spring concert. Performances will take place May 6 at 3 p.m. at the Holy Spirit Church, Monument Road in Orleans, and May 11 at 7:30 p.m. at the Federated Church of Hyannis, Main Street in Hyannis. Admission is free but donations are accepted to support the orchestra.

Lunch and lyrics with the Cape Cod Conservatory

On May 9 from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m., the Cape Cod Conservatory of Music and Arts will host an "Around Noon" event featuring a lecturer and lunch. This month's lecturer is Joe Scott, guitarist and Conservatory faculty member, who will discuss "The Art of the Guitar." Cost for the afternoon is $10 and includes lunch. For more information or to reserve tickets, call 508-362-2772.

Hyannis in harmony

The Cranberry Shores Chorus, a women's harmonizing group, holds its weekly rehearsals at the Federated Church of Hyannis, 320 Main St., every Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. New members are always welcome to join. Performances are held through the summer. For more information, call 508-240-0984 or visit www.cranberryshores.org.

Roadhouse Cafe is all jazzed up

The Roadhouse Cafe, 488 South St. in Hyannis, features weekly entertainment by local artists. On Monday nights the Roadhouse serves up live jazz, and on Friday and Saturday nights Matt Richard performs at the piano bar. Lou Colombo returns April 30 for Monday night jazz. For more information, call 508-775-2386 or visit www.roadhousecafe.com.

Schooner's makes musical waves

The Delaney Trio performs jazz every Friday and Saturday at 7 p.m. at Schooner's Restaurant, 372 Main Street in Hyannis. For more information, call 508-778-7588.

Jazz in Barnstable Village

The Barnstable Restaurant and Tavern offers Sunday jazz brunch from 12:30 to 2:30 p.m. across from the county courthouse on Route 6A in Barnstable village.

Grand music at the Grand Cru

The Grand Cru Wine Bar at The Cape Codder Resort & Spa, Route 132 in Hyannis hosts jazz nights weekly at 8 p.m. Tomorrow and May 5 Ann Austin performs, and on May 4 Bart Weisman will entertain.

For reservations or more information, call 508-771-3000.

Island sounds

The Island Merchant has moved into its new digs at 302 Main St. in Hyannis. On Thursdays, Mike Brooke performs jazz piano from 7 to 9 p.m. and on Fridays, Sara Leketa and friends offer up acoustic rock at 10 p.m.

Heritage Hotel has weekend shows

Chauncy's Restaurant and Lounge at Heritage Hotel on Main Street in Hyannis features live entertainment every weekend with complimentary hors d'oeuvres from 5 to 7 p.m. Call 508-833-0087.

On tap at the British Beer Company

The BBC offers up a mix of music and more every week. Tonight, Twenty Eight performs. Tomorrow the Shotgun Bandits will take the stage, on April 29 Cape favorites Syndicate will play and on the 30th the BBC will bring Wicked Trivia to the table from 7:30 to 9:30 p.m.

Jazz' n jam

The Cape Cod Claddagh Inn, Route 28 in West Harwich, hosts a weekly Sunday Jazz Jam With Bart Weisman when Bart plays with friends at 3 p.m.

Irish Village entertainment

Live music is on stage nightly at the Cape Cod Irish Village Restaurant at Route 28 in West Yarmouth.

Contra dances in Cotuit

A Contra dance is held the second Saturday of every month at Freedom Hall, 976 Main St. in Cotuit, with live music by John Alden & Friends. Beginners and singles are welcome and soft-soled shoes are recommended. All dances begin at 8 p.m. Admission is $6. Call 508-420-2188.

Traditional New England contra dance

A traditional New England contra dance will be held the fifth Saturday of each month from 8 to 11 p.m., with basic instruction offered at 7:45 p.m., at the North Falmouth Congregational Church, 155 Old Main Road in North Falmouth. Admission is $6 for adults and free for children.

APA offers encore performances

The Academy Playhouse in Orleans will present four encore performances of The Graduate May 3, 4 and 5 at 8 p.m. and 6 at 2 p.m. Tickets are $16.

CCftA brings a Mother's Day kick sans champagne

For a special Mother's Day event, the Cotuit Center for the Arts, 4404 Route 28 in Cotuit, will present an encore performance of Love, Cole on May 13 at 3 p.m. Tickets are $12 for CCftA members and $18 for non-members and can be reserved at 508-428-0669.

Chatham Drama Guild is in the dark

The Chatham Drama Guild, 134 Crowell Road in Chatham, will present the farce Black Comedy: Where Everything Happens in the Dark from May 4 to 27. Performances are Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m. and Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets are $16 for adults and $10 for students under 18. For more information or to reserve tickets, call 508-945-0510 or visit www.CapeTix.com.

HJT brings the really small stage to Cape Cod

Through May 13, Harwich Junior Theatre, 105 Division St. in West Harwich, will present Stuart Little. Shows will run Fridays at 7:30 p.m. and Saturdays and Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets are $18 for adults, $16 for seniors 65 and above and $12 for youth 21 and under. For more information or to order tickets call 508-432-2002.

Cape Rep offers underdog performance

Running May 10 through Jun 3, Cape Rep Theatre, Route 6A in Brewster, will present Topdog/Underdog. Performances run Thursdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m. and Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets are $20. For more information or to reserve tickets, call 508-896-1888 or visit www.caperep.org.

Cape Codder offers comedy and crooning

The Cape Codder Resort and Spa in Hyannis offers dinner theater every weekend. Shows include a buffet dinner.

Tickets are $45 per person. Reservations are suggested. For more information or to reserve tickets, call 508-771-3000 or visit www.CapeCodderResort.com.

APA wants a good fit for a glass slipper

On May 5 at 10:30 a.m., the Academy Playhouse in Orleans will hold auditions for its upcoming presentation of Disney's Cinderella. Those auditioning should bring sheet music, a short monologue and be prepared to dance. For more information call 508-255-3075.

BCC is looking for laughs

Through May 15, the Barnstable Comedy Club invites aspiring directors to submit one-act plays. Three plays will be selected to be produced. Actors will audition for the plays during June. For more information, call 508-362-6333

MISCELLANEOUS

Spaghetti dinner in WB

The West Barnstable Village Festival Committee holds its annual spaghetti supper on Sunday from 5 to 8 p.m. at the West Barnstable Fire Station. Admission is $8 for adults and $4 for the 12-and-under set.

Funds for furry friends

On May 5, the MSPCA of Cape Cod will host its Furry Affair Auction at the Cotuit Center for the Arts, 4404 Route 28 in Cotuit. The Cinco de Mayo event will feature auctions, entertainment by the Cape Cod Conservatory Jazz Band, cocktails, hors d'oeuvres and a raffle. Tickets are $45 and include two drinks and dinner from Ay Caramba. Proceeds benefit the MSPCA's Guardian Angel Fund. For more information or to purchase tickets, call 508-771-3452 or visit www.mspca.org/cape.

Farming for vendors

The Mid-Cape Farmers' Market is looking for vendors for its summer season. The Market is held Wednesdays from 8 a.m. to noon on Main Street in Hyannis from June 13 to Sept. 5. Farmers and vendors of local products are invited to participate. For more information, contact Gretel Norgeot at 508-255-8374 or greteln@capecod.net.

Hospital Auxiliary raffles dough for donations

The Barnstable branch of the Cape Cod Hospital Auxiliary is sponsoring a Save a Heart/Save a Life raffle. Grand prize in the raffle is $10,000 cash. A winner will be selected Sept. 13. Only 300 tickets will be sold. Each ticket can be purchased by one person for $100, two people for $50 each or by four people for $25 each. Remaining tickets will be sold July 19 and 20 and 26 and 27 and Aug. 9 and 10 at the hospital. All proceeds will benefit the Cardiac Care Center at the hospital.

For more information or to purchase tickets by phone, call 508-771-4390, 508-375-0376, 508-945-1792 or the volunteer office at Cape Cod Hospital at 508-862-5292.

Weathervane loves shutterbugs

Cape Cod Weathervane Company, 379 Iyannough Road, Unit 5 Rear in Hyannis, is sponsoring a photograph contest for its first catalog. First prize is $300. For more information, contact Beth at 1-800-460-1477 or Beth@capecodweathervanes.com or visit www.capecodweathervanes.com.

Help for teen parents

Cape Cod Child Development is accepting applications for enrollment in its teen parent program, available to parents 19 and younger. The program provides free full-time childcare and a variety of support services to teen parents and their children Cape wide. Call 1-800-974-8860 for more information.

Books for Barnstable

The Cape Cod Cooperative Extension Service and AmeriCorps, in cooperation with "Got Books?" has placed a book donation box in the Barnstable County complex on Route 6A in Barnstable village. The "Got Books?" program collects old books, CDs, DVDs, videos, records, software and sports memorabilia and holds charity book sales. The money is then given to nonprofit groups. Other books are given to schools and libraries in the area. For more information, call 508-375-6690 or visit www.gotbooks.com.

NOAH Center needs blankets

The NOAH Center emergency shelter for adults needs blankets to give away. New and used blankets may be dropped off at 77 Winter St. in Hyannis.

Mangia, mangia!

It's pasta night every Thursday between 5:30 and 8:30 p.m. at the Sons of Italy, 4996 Falmouth Road in Cotuit. And if that doesn't fill you up, stop by for an all-you-can-eat breakfast buffet Saturday mornings between 9 a.m. and 1 p.m.

Cape kids collect cash for cancer

Sunday from 8:30 a.m. to 1 p.m., the Quashnet K Kids, a Kiwanis-sponsored community service club, will hold a carwash and Red Sox and Patriots ticket raffle at the Mashpee Town Library. Proceeds from the event will go toward Angel's Hope, a Cape-based organization that financially assists families dealing with cancer. Tickets are available for $1 per ticket or $5 for six tickets. Winning tickets will be drawn the same day. For more information, call the Quashnet School at 508-539-1550.

Cruising for a cause

On May 12, the A.L.S. Charitable foundation will hold a Mother's Day "Cruise to Cure A.L.S," around Sesuit Harbor. The cruise will include a buffet lunch, cash bar and raffles. Tickets for the event are $55 and must be reserved by May 4. For more information or to reserve tickets call 508-759-9696 or visit www.alsfamily.org.

We Can offers aid for women

We Can, a women's advocacy group, will hold two free legal clinics for women on May 10. From 9 to 11 a.m. learn about workman's compensation and Social Security, and from 1 to 3 p.m. We Can will discuss family law. Clinics are held at We Can, 537 Main Street Suit 2H in Harwichport. To schedule a half-hour session call 508-430-8111.

Rockland Trust teams up with the troops

Through May 25, Rockland Trust banks across Cape Cod will collect donations for U.S. troops serving overseas. Donations can include paper and envelopes, snack foods, toiletries, disposable cameras, playing cards and games. Families with members serving overseas can also register for a care package through the bank.

Bud jewelry to benefit breast cancer

Sandwich jewelry designer Elisa Sullivan, owner of Swirls Jewelry, has created a breast cancer fundraiser necklace in cooperation with six-time breast cancer survivor Karen Cotton. The necklace features a mother-of-pearl carved flower, Swarvoski crystal accents and a ribbon or rubber cord. Through May 19, one-third of the proceeds will be donated in honor of Cotton to the Boston Avon Walk for Breast Cancer. The necklace costs $30 and can be purchased at www.swirlsjewelry.com or 617-763-7172.

Sandwich offers sharps collection

Beginning this week, the Sandwich Fire Department, 115 Route 6A, will collect full sharps containers. Seventeen other sharps collection locations are available across Cape Cod, as well. For information on locations, visit www.capecodextension.org.

Easter Seals offers summer registration

Registration has begun for two residential summer programs operated by Easter Seals for children, teens and young adults with disabilities. Camps in Maine and Connecticut offer support for campers ages six to 30, and five- and 12-day sessions are available. For more information or to register, contact Camp Manager Colleen Flanagan at 1-800--244-2756 ext. 410 or Camp@EasterSealsMa.net.

Green Briar's winter hours

Green Briar Nature Center's winter hours are Tuesday through Saturday from 10 a.m. until 4 p.m. Green Briar is located at 6 Discovery Hill Road off Route 6A in East Sandwich. For more information, call 508-888-6870.

American Lung Association breathes life into old cars

The American Lung Association of Massachusetts is looking for residents to donate used cars, trucks, vans, motorcycles and boats. Free pickup is available. For more information, call 1-800-577-LUNG or visit www.donateyourcar.com.

Help the homeless

Purchase a grocery gift card for use at Stop & Shop, Shaw's and Country Garden for the face value of $10 to $100 and use it for the full amount. Five percent of the purchase price will go to help prevent homelessness. Cards available at local churches, or Cape Cod Cooperative's West Barnstable office. Sponsored by the Barnstable Interfaith Council. For information, call 508-362-7131.

Singers wanted

The Chatham Chorale needs new members for the 2007 season. If interested in joining, call 888-556-2707. Rehearsals are held Thursday nights at the Cape Cod Covenant Church at the intersection of Airline Road and Setucket Road on the Dennis/Brewster line.

Hallet House open

The Captain Bangs Hallet House Museum, at 11 Strawberry Ln. off Route 6A in Yarmouthport, is a fully-furnished captain's home complete with maritime exhibits, costumes, artwork and more. Guided tours are at 1, 2 and 3 p.m. Thursday through Sunday. Admission is $8. For reservations or more information, call 508-375-0124.

Marines wanted!

The 2nd Marine Division Association is looking for new members. Vets and former 2nd Division Marines are wanted to participate in reunions and other events. Anyone interested in more information should call 760-365-2473 or visit www.2marine.com.

Boys and Girls Club collects cars

Getting a new car? Think about donating your unwanted vehicle, no restrictions, to the Boys & Girls Club for sale at auction later. Call 800-246-0493 for details.

Learn to fling!

The Callanish School of Celtic Arts leads beginning lessons in Highland Dance and Scottish Step Dance Monday afternoons at the West Barnstable Community Building on Route 149 and at the First Congregational Church of Yarmouthport on Route 6A on Wednesday afternoons. Ages 4 and up are welcome. Call 508-888-0107 for information.

Rover Dog to the rescue

Homes for Barnstable County area pets can be found via the Internet with the help of Rover Dog Rescue in Buzzards Bay, the MSPCA in Centerville, and People for Cats in West Falmouth, all of whom have joined Petfinder.com, the oldest and largest on-line database of homeless pets. For more information, e-mail roverdogrescue@hotmail.com

Foster and adoptive families needed

Social workers and local foster parents are present the fourth Thursday of every month from noon to 1 p.m. and 6 to 7 p.m. at the state Department of Social Services, 32 Commercial St. in South Yarmouth, to discuss foster parenting and adoption. Those interested should stop by or call 508-771-1727.

Coffee and an open mic

The YMCA of Cape Cod's coffeehouse for teens at Camp Lyndon in Sandwich will be held the second and fourth Saturday of each month from 7 to 9 p.m. Featured activities include an open mic, musicians, dancing, an art gallery, poetry readings and more. Teens are welcome to perform or just hang out. Admission is $2.

Cape Cod Conservation offers lectures and more

Tomorrow at 11 a.m., WXTK Garden Line host C.L. Fornari will speak. Today at 9 a.m. and tomorrow at 10 a.m., visit the Barnstable County Farm, Route 6A in Barnstable Village, to learn about growing mushrooms safely. Soil testing will be offered Saturday from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. For more information on the Cape Cod Conservation District, call 508-771-8757 or visit www.capecodcd.org.

Burgess Museum burgeoning with spring events

The Thornton W. Burgess Museum, 4 Water Street in Sandwich, will open for the season May 7. A variety of events for children and adults will be featured every month. Hours are 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Monday through Saturday and 1 p.m. to 4 p.m. Sundays. Admission is by donation. For a complete schedule of events, call 508-888-6870.

Land Trust celebrates Earth Day with spring cleaning

On Sunday beginning at 9 a.m., the Barnstable Land Trust will sponsor a clean-up of BLT lands. Participants should meet at 9 a.m. at Marstons Mills East Elementary School, 760 Osterville/West Barnstable Road in Marstons Mills. Trash bags, gloves and light refreshments will be provided. For more information call 508-771-2585.

Green Briar offers birding and more

Sunday from 2 to 3:30 p.m. at the Green Briar Nature Center, 6 Discovery Hill Road in East Sandwich, kids ages four and up and their families can learn about salamanders at the center's breeding pool. Shoes or boots suitable for muddy conditions are a must. Cost for the event is $5 for adult Burgess Society members, $3 for kid members, $7 for adult non-members and $4 for child non-members. Advance registration is required. Call 508-888-6870 for more information or to reserve a spot.

Every Monday, the Thornton W. Burgess Society will lead birding excursions with naturalist Phil Kyle. The trips will visit birding spots in the Upper and Mid-Cape areas. Birders are to meet at 8 a.m. at the Green Briar Nature Center, to carpool.

Trips are $12 for Burgess Society members and $16 for non-members. The society also offers birding trips throughout the month across the Cape on other days of the week. For more information or to register, call 508-888-6870.

Bird club hosts birding weekend

May 12 and 13, the Cape Cod Bird Club will host its second annual Birding Cape Cod Weekend, featuring a variety of birding walks and other events across Cape Cod. In Barnstable, visit the Bridge Creek Conservation Area at 8 a.m. on the 13th for a walk around the grounds. Walks are free and open to the public. For more information on the event, visit www.massbird.org/ccbc or contact Mary Keleher at 508-477-1473.

Fishing and fun with Trout Unlimited

The Cape Cod chapter of Trout Unlimited will hold their annual fly fishing camp May 11, 12 and 13 at the YMCA's Camp Burgess in Sandwich. The sleep-over camp will teach basic and advanced fly fishing techniques and includes all meals and tackle. Cost for the weekend is $249 for adults, $129 for teens 13 to 17; and $329 for one adult and one teen. Cost for TU members is $219. For more information or to reserve a spot, contact CCTU fishing camp director Scott Dietrich at 508-776-9667 or ccflyfish@hotmail.com

Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution

Redfield Auditorium, Water St., Woods Hole, 508-289-2398

Barnstable Land Trust

720 Main St., Hyannis. For more information, call 508-771-2585. The Barnstable Land Trust is a non-profit, community-based conservation organization offering information about preserving the open spaces on Cape Cod. For more information on the BLT, visit www.BLT.org.

Cape Cod Canal Visitor Center

Cape side of the Canal, Ed Moffit Drive, across from the Sandwich Coast Guard Station. For more information, call 508-833-9678. Closed for the season. Attractions include a retired 41-foot U.S. Army Corps of Engineers' patrol boat, real time radar and camera images of the Canal, a theater showing continuous presentations on the Canal history, bookstore, rangers presenting ongoing free programs and more.

Cape Cod National Seashore

Salt Pond Visitor Center, Nauset Road, off Route 6 in Eastham, 508-255-3421; Province Lands Visitor Center (closed for the season), Race Point Road, off Route 6 in Provincetown, 508-487-1256.

Cape Cod Museum of Natural History

Route 6A in Brewster. Nature walks, talks, lessons, trips, a museum shop and library, family programs and more are offered. Current exhibits include an interactive coastal exhibit, marine exhibits, birds and more. For more information, call 508-896-3867.

Massachusetts Audubon Society, Long Pasture Wildlife Sanctuary

345 Bone Hill Rd., Cummaquid. Call 508-362-7475 for detailed information.

Massachusetts Audubon Society, Long Pasture Wildlife Sanctuary

On May 5 from 9:30 to 11 a.m. and May 8 from 11:30 a.m. to 1 p.m., the society will offer a spring birding trip to the Popponesset spit to search for terns, piping plovers and other native birds. Attendees should meet at the Popponesset Beach Association parking lot, 153 Wading Place Road in Mashpee. Cost is $6 for members and $8 for non-members.

On May 5 from 3:30 to 8:30 p.m., ecologist Jon Way will lead a day of coyote study. Participants will learn coyote tracking techniques and will search for radio-collared coyotes. Attendees should meet at the Long Pasture Wildlife Sanctuary, 345 Bone Hill Road in Cummaquid. Cost is $35 for members and $40 for non-members.

For more information or to reserve a space, call 508-362-7475.

Waquoit Bay Reserve

Route 28, East Falmouth. Professional development courses are available for educators in fishing, oceans and coasts, saltwater studies, whales, local water issues, coastal habitats and more. For more information, call 508-349-2615.

Cape Cod Wildlife Center

185 Meadow Lane, West Barnstable. Have your questions about wildlife answered daily from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., or go to the Center's Web site at CapeWildlife.Org

The Center strongly urges the public to not touch wild animals. If you must do so, wear thick rubber gloves. Better yet, call your local animal control department and let the professionals handle the situation.

For more information about the center, call 508-362-0111 or visit www.capewildlife.org.

Nourishment for thought

"When a Nutrient Becomes a Nuisance: The Impact of Septic Systems on Water Quality" is Maggie Geist's topic May 3 at 5 p.m. when the executive director of the Association to Preserve Cape Cod leads a discussion in the community room of the Cape Cod Five Cents Savings Bank on Route 28 in Hyannis behind the Cape Cod Mall. To register for the free event, call Andrea at 508-771-2585 or send an e-mail to andrea@blt.org.

Cape wildlife sanctuary converses about climate change

As part of its public lecture series, tonight at 7 p.m. the Wellfleet Bay Wildlife Sanctuary in South Wellfleet will feature a lecture by Rob Pratt, senior vice president of the Henry P. Kendall Foundation's climate change program, on "Influencing Climate Change in New England." The event will take place at the sanctuary. Cost for the talk is $5 for Mass Audubon members and $7 for non-members, and registration is required. For more information or to register call 508-349-2615.

Museum of Natural History goes batty

On May 8 at 1:30 p.m., the Friends of the Cape Cod Natural History Museum will host a lecture by naturalist Irwin Schorr on "Bats, Bats, Bats." A friends business meeting will be held at 1 p.m. Cost for non-friends members is $3.

Library reads the letters of literature

As part of its "A Year in Letters" lecture series, on May 8 at 7 p.m. Sturgis Library, 3090 Main St. in Barnstable, will feature a free lecture by Federico Muchnik. Muchnik is the grandson of Arthur Miller's Spanish publisher and will present the letters from Miller to the Muchnik family. For more information, call 508-362-6636 or visit www.sturgislibrary.org.

Writers' Center offers advice for authors

On May 11, 12 and 13 at the Holiday Inn, 1127 Route 132 in Hyannis, the Cape Cod Writers' Center will host a series of lectures on "How to Self-publish and Market Your Book." Four lectures will introduce authors to the various aspects of self-publishing. For more information, a schedule of lectures and cost, call 508-420-0200 or visit www.capecodwriterscenter.org.

A walk into history with the Historical Society of Old Yarmouth

On May 5 at 2 p.m., the Historical Society of Old Yarmouth will host a walk with retired forester Jim Carlaw. Carlaw will lead a nature walk through historical areas of Yarmouth. Walkers should meet at the gatehouse behind Yarmouth Port Post Office on Route 6A. There is no cost for the walk. For more information call 508-362-3021.

CCMNH takes a stroll

The Cape Cod Museum of Natural History offers weekly walks throughout the spring across the Cape. Connie Boyce leads three-to-four mile walks from 10 a.m. to noon.

Cost for the walks is $4 for museum members and $6 for non-members. Van trips are $1 extra. For more information call Connie Boyce by 8 a.m. the morning of the walk at 508-394-2683.

Sandwich expedition

Explore the oldest town on Cape Cod, Sandwich, year-round on a 6.2-mile walk as part of the Walk'n Mass Volkssport Club. Call 508-291-1162.

Take the Hyannis-JFK family compound walk

Walk Hyannis and enjoy ocean views on a 10K jaunt beginning at the Heritage House Hotel, 259 Main St. in Hyannis. Walk sponsored by the Walk'n Mass Volkssport Club. Start times are daily between sunrise to sunset. For more information, call 508-775-7000.
